main_text:
Attributes in the Ethics
1. Attributes in the Ethics

Before discussing the theory of attributes in the Ethics, it
will be helpful to keep in mind a rudimentary sketch of the general
structure of Spinoza’s
 ontology:[2]



Attributes/Substance:
Thought ––– God
––– Extension 


|

| 

Infinite Modes:
Infinite Intellect
      
Motion and Rest 


|

| 

Finite Modes:
A Mind

A Body 


There is only an infinite substance (1P14), that is, there are no
created substances. The infinite substance consists of infinite
attributes (1D6). Every mode, be it finite or infinite, must be
conceived through an attribute (1D5, 1P10Schol, 2P6 and 2P6Dem).
Finally, what other philosophers consider to be “created
substances,” such as my mind (as well as my body), are finite
modes for Spinoza
 (1P11).[3]
hierarchy_title: Spinoza’s Theory of Attributes || Attributes in the Ethics
